div1.p: Reed describes methods of experimentation and the progress of the work at Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 2, 1900
div1.opener:
Please promptly
acknowledge
receipt of the
Check! Boo!
Boo! Love
to “Doogy”-
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
Dec. 2nd, 1900.
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
How glad
I was to get your sweet
letters of Tuesday and Sat-
urday- And my darling
wifie is really much
better and able to get down
stairs once more? How
perfectly delightful! and
how delighted I am to
hear of it! You sweet,
patient thing, what a
seige of it you must
have had! Now that you
begin to talk of your toe,
I feel assured, too, that
your attack was really one
of gout- You've been living
entirely too high, lovie, dear,
and been consuming too
many of the good things of
this life! You will have
to eschew juicy steakes
Steaks, welsh Rarebits,
and Johannes Barley corn,
and come down to milk,
white meat, and succu-
lent vegetables, such
as grow in Keewaydin's
terraced garden; or
there will be more
trouble in store for you.
Eat but little and take
lots of outdoor exercise,
and look not upon the wine,
these are to be the guiding
principles of your future
conduct! my! it strikes
your old Mr Mantee that
with dear aunt Jane's
Eczema and your gout,
the Mint-bed by the pump
will run riot! Certainly
precious silk petty-coat
and I can never keep that
mint properly nipped!
what a joke on two large,
fat, juicy ladies!- Eczema
and gout- Oh! how “Tarantula
Juice” makes its devotees
uncomfortable at times! In-
deed, precious Oomsey, I am
so rejoiced to hear that
you are so much better and
free of pain- It made me
sad to think of your lameness
and confinement in-doors.
But now that you can go
to the matinee and have a
quiet little chuckle, with
those two first- class, chuck-
-lers, Lucy and Blossom,
I know that you will be-
gin to take some com-
fort in life- Of course,
Miss Lucy was sweet
and good to you, while sick,
she couldn't be otherwise,
even though she tried!
What a comfort to have
such dear, kind people to
drop in & add their mite
to your comfort! It would
have been strange if Dr
Nash & Carter hadn't ad-
mired your bright, cosy
room, all the brighter and
more cheerful by the ar-
tistic touch of sweet Miss
Room-fixer. What has be-
come of that precious
daughter of mine, that she
doesn't write to her father?
stir her up a little, Mother
dear- By the way, I enclose
in this letter a check for
$258.34 which Beechner can
C1
B9
take to the Bank for you-
You don't have to endorse
it ats all- Be certain to
give Beechner your depos-
it-book- I will write to
Mr Meyers, by this mail,
to send Beechner over, &
you must give him 3 street
-car tickets when he comes,
so as to cover his car-
fare in going to the bank
& returning- I have kept
some cash for myself in
case I should need it,
my expenses have been very
little since I came, & they won't
be much for this month- I
hope that Johnnie Moore
has finished his work
at Keewaydin by this time.
How sweet in dear Mrs.
Compfton to come to see you again,
Give her my love & to Mrs. Gor-
don & Halstead when you see
them- As regard the outcome
of our observations, I have
thought very carefully over
what the world would have
to say, in case any very se-
rious thing would happen-
Already the spanish papers
in Havana have called
us “Savages” & “Barbarians!
I think that I wrote you
concerning that, didn't I?
The Spanish consul, however,
a gentleman of sense, fully
endorses our inoculations.
But I am doing nothing
for which we should be
censured- No one is
subjected to any experiment,
who does not give in writing,
signed by himself, his freeest
consent, & after the full danger
has been explained to him-
we have Dr Cooke & two men of
the Hospital Corps, now occupy-
-ing the house that contains infected
clothing- They went in on Friday
evening, novr 30th. I only re-
quire them to sleep in this house.
During the day, they occupy a
large tent nearby their house.
Last Tuesday three men -- one
american & two spaniards were
bitten by infected mosquitoes-
Friday morning, the american
had slight fever & headache
which lasted all day- Today
slight fever with dizziness-
whether he will develope any
further symptoms, I can't tell
yet -- one spaniard has slight
fever, this afternoon, the other
has none- Dr Agramonte ap-
plied two better infected insects
to each of the spaniards, this
afternoon- I have one amer-
ican & two other Spaniards in
camp, whom we shall inoc-
ulate by bites within the
next 6 days- we are now
in much better shape to keep
our mosquitoes alive at
summer temperatures in a
regularly prepared room
properly heated- This
room is located at our
station- of course, Drs C.
& Agramonte superintend
the infection & raising of
the insects entirely- I
hatch out here larvae
from the eggs of insects that
we catch here in the garrison
where there is no yellow
fever. So the work goes on.
Of course, I am very anxious
as to the outcome, but I am
not worrying over what the
world may say, as I feel
that only good must grow out
of our work

Monday morning - Dec. 3rd- How
are my sweet girls this beau-
tiful morning? Still soundly a-
-sleep, while papa is pen-
ning these concluding words,
I guess- well, asleep or awake,
they are his precious
babies- Give much love to
Miss Lucy & Mrs. Dorsey -- also
to Miss Mason & Miss Thompson-
Regards to the others- You must
make Ida a nice present- write
often- Kisses & love & love & Kisses
for my darling children-
